Statistical Learning  6. Consciousness 7 Disorder of attention 8. Decision making . During the final classes you will learn how basic knowledge from cognitive psychology can be applied to solve real-life problems. The format of the seminar will be a discussion of one  target article, and student presentations, each week. Target articles for each week will be "classic" articles representing early and/or important studies on a specific topic. Reading is done using Perusall. The quality of comments is assessed. In class, all students prepare for a presentation in class. This will be done in groups. The final assessment will involve the writing of a research proposal and possibly a few exam questions. column7: Faculty of Behavioural and Movement Sc.
column11: The requirement to participate is the completion of the basic Cognitive Neuroscience and Neuropsychology course. Alternatively, students may study the required literature by self-study.
column12: This is an advanced course that presents recent developments in the field of cognitive neuroscience, with a focus on overarching ideas. Why do we have a brain to begin with? What is the relationship between cognition and action? Can psychiatric disorders be reduced to brain dysfunction? And can artificial systems ever truly think and learn like humans? The course provides an overview of important cognitive and neuroscientific debates with a focus on influential theories, their strengths and weaknesses, their methodological implications and their empirical support. We will also explore what are important future directions for the field of cognitive neuroscience.

The course introduces students to the field of international security, its main concepts, and debates. We begin with an overview of how the field has developed and how international security has been defined. We discuss the merits and problems of broadening the notion of international security. We then introduce the security dilemma as a useful approach to analyze security in the international system (as well as in weak and civil war-torn states). We will discuss the role of international norms, international institutions, and a range of non-state groups in mitigating the security dilemma and managing security issues.

column1: Selected Issues: Global Political Economy and Geopolitics
column12: This course deals with issues within two major fields of International Relations (IR): global political economy and geopolitics. Traditionally, the field of IR has been subdivided in the fields of international security and international (global) political economy. As a consequence of major transformations of the international system (end of the Cold War, globalization, climate change), the boundaries between these subfields have blurred. As the same time, against the background of the rise of China and other emerging powers, a declining American hegemony, and a general fraying of the liberal world order and rising interstate rivalries, questions of international security are increasingly framed (by policy-makers and scholars alike) through the use of a concept that until recently was associated with that of bygone era: that of geopolitics. Geopolitics here is seen as interacting with geo-economics.

This course introduces students to the current state of research within the field of global environmental governance. Global environmental change is one of the great challenges humankind is facing today. Humans now influence almost all biological and physical systems of the planet. Scientists today see mounting evidence that the entire earth system now operates well outside the normal state exhibited over the past 500,000 years, and that human activity is generating change that extends well beyond natural variability – in some cases, alarmingly so – and at rates that continue to accelerate. The perennial question from a social science perspective is how to organize the co-evolution of societies and their surrounding environment, in other words, how to develop effective and equitable governance solutions for today’s global problems.

This course draws on cutting-edge research from selected areas of political science to understand some of the most important challenges that democratic politics faces today, for instance democratic backsliding, the rise in populism, internationalisation, digital technology, economic crisis, and political fragmentation. The course aims to weigh the available insights and evidence – theoretical, descriptive and causal – to arrive at the fullest possible understanding of key themes in contemporary politics.

column1: Seeing is Believing: Film and Religion and the Construction of Sacredness Beyond the Limits of Representation and Articulation.
column10: Extra curricular course for VU students, Secondary subject for non-VU students, Part of an Exchange Programme
column12: This course explores the limits of truth-telling and representation. Semantic and text-based approaches have a limited capacity to express the lived experience of people. This is perhaps most obvious when it comes to individual or collective trauma
column13: to the void of reality that is beyond expression (the ‘real’ in Lacanian thinking)
column14: and to the experienced presence of sacred and divine realities - three experiences that are often referred to as the ‘unspeakable’, as something beyond articulation. In comparison to purely verbal representations of such experiences, film offers a rich repertoire of audiovisual tools that offers many opportunities of representing realities that are difficult to express in language. In this course, such filmic representations are explored by analyzing the cinematographic and narrative elements of film. In addition, the course discusses the limits of filmic representation as well, for film has its limits too when it comes to traumatic and sacred experiences: they can be not only unspeakable, but also ‘unimaginable’. However, film can at the very least probe the boundaries of what can be expressed
column15: filmic methods and techniques can be mobilized to show what it means not to be able to imagine, not to be able to speak. In the third place, this course not only explores the representation of the ‘unspeakable’
column16: it also applies a film as religion approach that enables students to understand the ‘religious work’ of film: how film may mediate (reveal, produce and transmit) sacred and divine realities and experiences. Students learn to unravel the representation and mediation of the unspeakable by carefully analyzing the cinematographic and narrative elements of film.

column12: The goal of this course is to characterize, classify and interpret a selected number of terrestrial, coastal and marine sedimentary environments in terms of their geomorphology, facies distribution, sedimentary and post-depositional processes, stratigraphy and paleoclimatic significance. Gedetailleerde faciesanalyse vormt de belangrijkste basis voor een paleomilieuinterpretatie van carbonaatgesteenten.

The course will start off by ensuring that you are up to speed in terms of the macrostructural and discursive features of academic texts in general and the specific kind of text you are writing in particular – a report on quantitative research, a report on qualitative research, or a methods paper. Centre stage is then given to aspects of coherent text and to linguistic devices that English uses to express complex ideas: we introduce basic principles, give you practice in analysing and reformulating defective text segments, and give you a checklist that you can use when editing your own text. The idea underlying this approach is that writing essentially involves rewriting and rewriting.

column7: Faculty of Behavioural and Movement Sc.
column12: This course will be based on the principles of practice-based learning. Students will actively learn how to write and present through hands-on experience. The course consists of two parts: a writing part and a presenting part. In the writing part of this course, students will learn how to write a scientific paper on survey data and learn how to design, structure, and revise the Introduction, Methods, Results, Discussion, and Abstract sections in order to bring across their message in the best possible way. Students will practice giving feedback on each other’s work as peer-reviewer. In the presentation part of this course, students will learn how to optimise their presenting skills by focusing on both verbal and non-verbal communication, controlling their nerves, maintaining a safe environment and controlling their voice and body. Students practice with designing an oral presentation, giving an oral presentation for different audiences, and answering questions about their research.

column12: Science in Archaeology 2 contains a continued introduction and practical application of scientific methods that can be used in archaeological research. Each student in Archaeology encounters problems and specific questions in the field or in the laboratory that relate to the age and prospection of the site, the floral signature of the surrounding landscape, palaeoclimatological data, as well as the formation and preservation potential of the archaeological assemblage. In this course an introduction and basic instruction into the variable methodology of Science in Archaeology is presented by several specialists in this field.

column10: Extra curricular course for VU students
column12: In this course, the theoretical and technical basis of various science methods used in Archaeology will be treated, as well as their position within this discipline. Several case studies will show both the potential and the limitations of these methods. Furthermore, practical training will be offered through group and individual assignments. The data sets used during the practicals will come from current research projects at UvA and VU.

column1: Science and Society in Historical Perspective
column10: Extra curricular course for VU students, Secondary subject for non-VU students, Open course, Part of an Exchange Programme
column12: We are used to thinking of science as the prime shaper of our modern world, but how exactly does that work? How have the sciences come to play this role in our society and, reversely, how have societal and political concerns impacted the scientific enterprise? In this course we will study the changing relationship between science and society over the centuries from several points of view. We will examine how scientists have dealt with the public. We will study science’s relationship to religion and to art. And we will ask how Western science really is, tracing how many cultures have shaped our knowledge. To address these questions, we will both use historical literature, videos and podcasts and original source texts and pictures.

column10: Extra curricular course for VU students, Secondary subject for non-VU students, Open course, Part of an Exchange Programme
column12: NA

column10: Extra curricular course for VU students, Secondary subject for non-VU students, Open course
column12: Hoe kun je je publiek boeien vanaf de eerste zin? Hoe schrijf je een pakkende tekst? Deze vragen houden de literatuur sinds de klassieke oudheid bezig en de antwoorden zijn ook buiten de literatuur relevant. Immers, een advocaat moet zijn gehoor weten te overtuigen van de onschuld van zijn cliënt of van verzachtende omstandigheden. En een CEO moet zijn bedrijf goed weten te ‘verkopen’. Na enkele introducerende colleges over de klassieke retorica waarbij je je traint in het schrijven van een zakelijk gestructureerde tekst, is er elke week een bekende schrijver of journalist te gast op college: studenten lezen en analyseren vooraf een van zijn of haar teksten, bereiden een interview voor en gaan tijdens het bezoek van de schrijver met hem/haar in gesprek over hun werk. Als gasten worden zowel creatieve schrijvers (o.a. de Vrije Schrijver), als bekende journalisten uitgenodigd (bijvoorbeeld Maxim Februari, Elsbeth Etty, Geert Mak, Abdelkader Benali).

column10: Extra curricular course for VU students, Secondary subject for non-VU students
column12: Onder leiding van de ‘vrije schrijver’ en Jacqueline Bel wordt een bezoek gebracht aan vier schrijvers. Elk van de bezoeken wordt in de daaraan voorafgaande week grondig voorbereid op basis van de lectuur van een of meer werken van deze auteur. Telkens vormt één werk, in combinatie met het zoeklicht 'poëtica', het uitgangspunt voor deze bezoeken. Vragen die aan de orde komen zijn: wat is de literatuuropvatting van deze schrijver? Welke kwesties houden hem/haar bezig? Hoe gaat de schrijver te werk? In hoeverre is het schrijven voor hem of haar een beroep?

column10: Extra curricular course for VU students, Secondary subject for non-VU students, Open course
column12: Het doel van deze module is drieledig: allereerst verwerven studenten kennis van de Nederlandse literatuurgeschiedenis (concepten, auteurs, tijdschriften, literaire werken, jaartallen, cultuurhistorische achtergronden etc.). Ten tweede leren studenten te reflecteren op deze kennis: zij laten zien dat zij verbanden kunnen leggen tussen literair-historische begrippen onderling en deze begrippen kunnen relativeren. Daarnaast kunnen zij laten zien dat periodiseren en categoriseren niet onproblematisch is. Dit hangt immers altijd samen met specifieke uitgangspunten en selectiecriteria. Ten derde is de student op basis van de voor deze periode typische kenmerken en genres in staat enkele creatieve opdrachten te maken. Uiteindelijk is de student vertrouwd met de belangrijkste periodes en richtingen die binnen de traditionele literatuurgeschiedschrijving voor het tijdvak 1920 tot heden worden onderscheiden en is de student in staat de gelezen teksten op basis van hun formele en thematische kenmerken te typeren, tegen hun cultuurhistorische, institutionele en maatschappelijke achtergrond te plaatsen en in verband te brengen met een theoretisch begrip als ‘poëtica’.

column10: Extra curricular course for VU students, Secondary subject for non-VU students, Open course
column12: In deze module maken de studenten kennis met de Nederlandse literatuur van ongeveer 1720 tot circa 1920. De student verwerft kennis van de belangrijkste literair-historische periodes, richtingen of tendensen[, met een verzameling representatief geachte teksten als uitgangspunt: voorstel: schrappen]. De periode 1720-1920 werd gekenmerkt door politieke revoluties (zoals de Franse revolutie (1789), de Bataafse Revolutie (1794-1799), de Belgische Opstand (1830), de Russische Revolutie (1917) en de industriële revolutie (de ‘IJzeren Eeuw’). Ook op literair gebied vonden er revoluties plaats, van schrijvende vrouwen in de achttiende eeuw en de introductie van het naturalisme in Nederland aan het eind van de negentiende eeuw tot de elkaar snel afwisselende avant-gardebewegingen in het begin van de twintigste eeuw. Deze cursus biedt een chronologisch overzicht van de belangrijkste periodes en richtingen die binnen de traditionele literatuurgeschiedschrijving voor het tijdvak 1720-1920 worden onderscheiden. [Periodiseren en categoriseren is echter niet onproblematisch. Dit hangt immers altijd samen met specifieke uitgangspunten en selectiecriteria. Belangrijk is daarom dat de student zich aan de hand van de literatuurgeschiedenissen verdiept in vooronderstellingen van de literatuurgeschiedschrijving zelf. Voorstel: schrappen] De cursus is ingedeeld in zes modules. Drie modules hebben betrekking op de achttiende eeuw, drie modules op de lange negentiende eeuw (tot ongeveer 1920).

column10: Extra curricular course for VU students, Secondary subject for non-VU students
column12: In deze module maken de studenten kennis met de Nederlandse literatuur van de Middeleeuwen tot de vroege 18de eeuw. Die literatuur is voor een deel vreemd en anders dan de moderne letterkunde, tegelijkertijd is er veel herkenbaar en zelfs actueel. In dit college, dat de periode 1100-1720 bestrijkt, worden de Middeleeuwen, rederijkerstijd, renaissance en het classicisme behandeld aan de hand van een syllabus en een keuze aan teksten. Uit de Middeleeuwen komen onder meer de ridderroman en religieuze lyriek aan bod. De rederijkerij is een cultureel wapen in de handen van met name de stedelijke burgerij. Vanaf 1550 begint de renaissance, auteurs gaan zich richten naar (meestal aan de oudheid ontleende) voorschriften, voorbeelden en theorieën. Tegelijkertijd vinden er belangrijke ontwikkelingen plaats in de politieke en religieuze situatie in de Nederlanden, die leiden tot de vorming van de Republiek. In de zeventiende eeuw, de Gouden Eeuw, groeit ons land uit tot een wereldmacht. Bij de behandeling van de teksten ligt de nadruk, behalve op de literaire ontwikkelingen, ook steeds op de maatschappelijke rol die teksten in de samenleving hebben vervuld, van statusverhoging tot politiek wapen, en van vermaak tot emancipatoire kracht. Aan de hand van een individuele praktijkopdracht krijgt de student een basisvaardigheid in het omgaan met de wetenschappelijk hulpmiddelen voor het vak. Ook maken de studenten creatieve opdrachten waarin ze hun kennis van de oudere literatuur verwerken.

column12: In deze module maken de studenten kennis met de Nederlandse literatuur van de Middeleeuwen tot de vroege 18de eeuw. column12: Deze cursus is gericht op het verder ontwikkelen van academische schrijfvaardigheden van studenten uit de premaster Pedagogische Wetenschappen. column12: In de hedendaagse zakelijke wereld wordt van een succesvol bedrijf niet langer alleen verwacht dat het winstgevend is. Integriteit en maatschappelijke verantwoordelijkheid zijn steeds crucialer geworden. Bedrijven lopen het risico om publiekelijk afgerekend te worden op onethisch gedrag, zoals het produceren van producten met schadelijke effecten op het milieu, de volksgezondheid of bevolkingen in andere landen. Naast het voorkomen van reputatieschade, biedt maatschappelijk verwantwoord ondernemen ook aanzienlijke kansen. Het kan merken versterken, klant- en werknemerstevredenheid vergroten en uiteindelijk winst genereren. Een doordachte strategie op gebied van maatschappelijk verwantwoord ondernemen, ook wel bekend als ‘Business Ethics Management’, is daarom onmisbaar. In dit domein moeten bedrijven omgaan met verschillende belanghebbenden, waaronder nationale regeringen, NGOs en internationale organisaties.

column12: The course cover three main themes. The first theme is "Getting to know yourself and the work field."Student will learn about the work-field of social and organizational psychology through exercises during the tutorials and by conducting a network meeting. In a professional portfolio students will reflect on their professional attitude, work field orientation, and own strength and weaknesses. The second theme is "Presenting yourself and your work." Students will gain professional presentation skills by giving an oral and poster presentation. The third theme is "Training your peers." Students will develop a training and give this training to their fellow students. During the course special attention will be given to the preparation of a professional CV and developing students' social and professional skills (e.g., time management, networking, creativity).

column10: Extra curricular course for VU students, Secondary subject for non-VU students, Open course, Part of an Exchange Programme
column12: What does it mean when a robot steps out of your computer in physical space and starts interacting with humans as if it were a social entity itself? This course will address various aspects that come into play when physically present robots interact with humans. This course focuses mainly on social robots, humanoids in particular, suited for communicative purposes. We will discuss both sides of the coin: perspectives from the robot-side as well as perspectives from the user-side. Differences and similarities with common computer-based AI (cf. avatars, chatbots) are discussed in comparison to human-robot interaction, exemplified by main application areas (e.g., eldercare, education). Basic models and relevant aspects of the psychology of the user and ethical aspects are also discussed. If robots start talking to humans by themselves, how can they understand each other? Lectures will therefore also address the basics of the understanding of language (e.g., Natural Language Processing (NLP)). How to translate theoretical models into effective computer models is another challenge that will not only be lectured on but also practiced. A team of lecturers with the respective expertise will lecture on the wide variety of topics in this course. Several practical tutorials/workshops accompany the lectures to gain hands-on experience regarding the complexities of human-robot interaction.

The first half of the course will cover the basics of robotics and robot control. Topics will include  forward/inverse kinematics, modeling of robots, Denavit-Hartenberg, the basics of dynamics, trajectory planning and optimization and control algorithms.

column12: The second year of the Research Master’s Program in Social Psychology will be concluded with two extensive research projects (2 x 18 EC). These two projects together will make up the students’ Master’s theses, leading to a Master of Science (MSc) degree. Students will conduct an original research project leading to a written report in the style of a journal article. Most common is to conduct two consecutive studies (one for each project) and combine them into one single thesis.

column12: You will learn the fundamentals of banking and the working of banks in the financial markets. What are the risks that banks must deal with? How can you identify, monitor, and report the different risk types? How are they aligned with each other, and finally, how can you manage these risks with all this knowledge? The course will cover balance sheet management and its impact on the business model. How can you optimize your balance sheet and develop a sustainable business model taking all the risks into account? In addition, you will be able to interpret banking regulations and have a good view of the supervisory authorities.

column12: Risk and health communication are often used to inform people about health risks and to motivate them to adopt healthy behavior. To develop effective health campaigns and interventions, you – as a communication scientist – need knowledge about the factors that predict risk and health behavior, how you can influence these factors through communication, and how you can overcome potential obstacles you can encounter while persuading your audience. In this course we therefore discuss theory and research about predicting and changing risk and health behavior. In addition, we discuss, for instance, the role of message factors, and how campaign and intervention effects can be measured.

The third year of the post-graduation course is dedicated to the finalization of your research project. The primary objective during this phase is to write the thesis, typically in the format of a scientific article. You will present your completed thesis as part of the final exam, marking the culmination of the research track.
NA

In the second year of the post-graduation course, your focus shifts towards data collection and planning for data analysis. You gather the necessary data for your research project, which may involve conducting experiments, surveys, interviews, or collecting relevant literature. During this phase, you also start drafting your thesis, which includes organizing the collected data and preparing for the subsequent analysis.
NA

During the first year of the post-graduation course, your primary goal is to establish your research question or research design. Additionally, you develop a research proposal, which is a detailed plan outlining the objectives, methodology, and expected outcomes of your research project. This phase sets the foundation for your entire research project and ensures you that the research question and design are well-defined and approved.

column12: From the nineteenth century onwards, international organizations started to interact with state authorities in new and myriad ways. Some of these international organizations were established as networks and agreements between nation-states, while others were created by actors of civil society, independently and sometimes in opposition to the structures of national governments. Both international governmental organizations (IGOs) and international non-governmental organizations (INGOs) grew in importance and played a crucial role in social, economic, and political developments over the last 150 years.

column10: Extra curricular course for VU students
column12: Many Southeast Asian countries have a modern history of European colonialism, and of political movements, conflicts and revolutions that led to their independence in the mid-twentieth century. These processes have significant contemporary legacies in Southeast Asia and Europe. This course reflects on colonialism and decolonisation through focusing on sources from, and narratives and debates about, key moments in these histories in Southeast Asia. It attends to the global, political nature of some of these processes, but also to important local variations in how colonialism was established, contested, and dismantled in different contexts. Students will  critically engage with how sources are used by various institutions and actors in Southeast Asia and Europe to narrate histories of colonialism and decolonisation, and their relevance to communities in both places today.

column10: Extra curricular course for VU students
column11: See Education and Examination Regulations BA MKDA.
column12: This working group will study design, applied art and / or material culture from a specific starting point: Design and Time. The history of design is bound up with conceptions of time as it relates to space, the body and impacts the psyche. This course examines how designed objects were shaped by the emergence of clock time, the rhythms of work and leisure, the increasing speed of life and communications as well as ideas of the past and future.

This course aims at preparing the student for screening, reading, and understanding academic literature. This is particularly useful in particular for the master project, where the student should consider relevant literature for the research question at hand. Getting acquainted with the literature consists of two elements: (i) being able to read and study in depth a specific academic paper, and (ii) carrying out a review (desk research) of scientific literature related to a chosen research question. Both of these elements are addressed during the seminar.

column10: Extra curricular course for VU students

column12: As museum curators, exhibition planners and/or researchers, art historians are expected to be able to conduct solid research, both on individual art objects and wider art historical questions, as well as to present and develop creative ideas for an intelligent, exciting and art-historically sound presentation of an ensemble of artworks. This course prepares you for all of this by intensively guiding you in formulating and elaborating a concept for a (virtual) exhibition, for which you will write the catalogue. The course includes exercises in various skills (including dBase) to prepare you for the working field, excursions to relevant institutes and guest lectures by researchers experienced in this type of research. For your catalogue, you formulate your own questions, which you elaborate in an introduction and in entries on 5 self-chosen and researched works of art.

column12: The Architecture Research Seminar is focused on analyzing and interpreting spatial plans and designs. The subject of the seminar varies each year and will be announced in advance through Canvas. The lecture series starts with the study and joint discussion of the professional, spatial and historical context of the chosen architectural, urban design and/or landscape architectural ensemble, subject or period. Then several case studies are analyzed and interpreted together using the available visual, design and presentation material(sketches, drawings, models) and written primary and secondary sources. Each student then formulates an individual research theme that is further questioned, researched and contextualized and reports on it in the form of a scientific article or a comparable piece of work.

Beyond statistics, political scientists do research by means of qualitative methods. The aim of this course is dual. On the one side, this course aims to develop qualitative research skills by doing this type of research. A large portion of the course is spent on developing interview skills: from the making questions to finding interviewees, conducting the interviews to finally reporting results and analysing these results.

This course requires the students to apply the academic and research skills they have already acquired within the first and second years of political science at a more advanced level. This will be done in the form of a group research project. The research project will have to address a relevant question pertaining to the content of the political science courses they have taken so far.

column10: Extra curricular course for VU students
column12: In response to the idea that ancient letters present the direct, unfiltered representation of historical events or personal thoughts, scholars have started to examine their rhetorical and literary aspects. As highlighted in scholarship, ancient letters are meticulously crafted documents composed for specific purposes. A crucial aim is the formation and representation of identity, of both the individual authors and groups. This aim is not just evident from the content and literary form of many letters, but also informs the processes of selection and compilation underlying the formation of letter collections in Antiquity, which were similarly driven by concerns about self-representation and identity.

column12: Research Design and Methods is focused around academic writing in general and writing a thesis in business administration in specific. Often, students find writing difficult or do not know how to start
column13: especially concerning the literature review. This course aims to aid students with reading literature, reviewing literature, specifying research questions, aims and objectives and writing a research proposal. Focus is especially given on structuring the process and reflection upon both process and writings. RDM basically consists of working groups, where we use forms as Delphi methods, pitch presentations and smaller discussion groups to enable students to see what other have done and to critically assess (reflect upon) their own work. The main advantage is that students are forced to work, read and write already from the start. Experience learns that continuously working on the (preparations for a) thesis lead to a much higher success of finishing in time.

column10: Extra curricular course for VU students, Secondary subject for non-VU students, Open course, Part of an Exchange Programme
column12: The course begins with an introductory lecture for all students, which explains the purpose of a research proposal and its key components and explains the logic and requirements of the course. This is followed by weekly parallel workshop-style tutorials. Each tutorial will cover the same content and will be organized in the same way: Tutors will provide additional input in the form of lectures and informal discussions on how to produce a research design for an MSc thesis and how to improve important soft skills. Students will moreover have room to work on their proposals during the tutorials and give each other peer feedback. Weekly homework related to the different elements of a research proposal will help students to stay on track and develop their proposals in a step-by-step approach. The complementary academic writing module will give students the opportunity to work on the structure and style of their text.

A good requirements specification is critical for software project success. This course gives an introduction to processes, methods, and representation forms for specifying and managing requirements. It also gives an overview of the whole software development lifecycle.

column1: Replacement, Refinement and Reduction of animal experiments applying human cells in culture
column10: Extra curricular course for VU students, Secondary subject for non-VU students, Open course, Part of an Exchange Programme
column12: The utilisation of whole animal studies in biological applications such as drug development has inherent ethical concerns, thus there is an impetus to develop non-animal models which may even bring advantages. Human cell culture offers a great tool in various research areas, including in the field of pharmacology and toxicology. Human cell culture systems often provide numerous advantages over animal experiments, including human relevance, reduced cost and the possibility to study mechanistic approaches. Nevertheless, choosing the best available cell model for the respective research question is critical. Furthermore, recent advances and cell culture methods and new techniques, including 3D cultures and organ on chip models evolve rapidly in this field. This course covers the basic understandings in cell culture methods as well as recent developments of advanced culturing techniques and compares different available human cell models, including (cancer) cell lines, primary cells or stem cells, such as induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSC).

Myths express how things are fundamentally intertwined with the community that experiences these stories as of crucial value to their own way of life and identity. Myths are binding

Students will learn to see how stories of migration and exile contributed to the religious identity of Jews, Christians and Muslims. It provides students with an overview of the diversity of Amsterdam's religious heritage and discusses how, throughout history, religious majorities and minorities were able to claim a space within Amsterdam. Students will contribute to a larger research-project. The goal of this project is to collect to stories of migrants

column12: This course addresses the important question of the relationship of contemporary and past religions (Buddhism, Christianity, Hinduism, Islam, Shinto, Greek and Babylonian religions) to gender. Gender issues related to male and female models in religious narratives, historical shifts in the religious status of women, mother goddesses and female power, and religious views of homosexuality will be addressed across cultures and religions. The central focus will be to discover underlying patterns of similarity and difference. Moreover, in two afternoon sessions and one morning session a link will be made between historical patterns in various traditions, and contemporary interpretations of and discussions on

column10: Extra curricular course for VU students, Secondary subject for non-VU students, Open course, Part of an Exchange Programme
column12: Popular culture is frequently perceived to be artificial, superficial and secular. However, research suggests that popular culture may function as a repertoire from which people draw in their search for (religious) meaning and a cultural site where religious practices are played out and religious feelings can be experienced. Movies, games, dance events, pop music, music festivals, media events, virtual worlds and other forms of popular culture seem to be not only entertaining, but may also be important in people’s search for (religious) meaning.

column10: Extra curricular course for VU students
column12: This course treats the main characteristics of, and approaches to, religion in the Ancient Near East and the Greco-Roman world. The lectures give an overview of the deities, religious life, rituals, and customs in each of these regions, with attention for possible interconnections. In discussing the various theoretical approaches towards religion, students will learn the - often implicit - theoretical assumptions in the scholarly literature, and gain insight into the coherence between religious changes and societal developments.

column9: prof. dr. R.B. ter Haar Romeny
column10: Extra curricular course for VU students, Secondary subject for non-VU students, Open course, Part of an Exchange Programme
column12: We tend to think of religions in terms of packages of beliefs and practices defined by institutions. Members of a faith or denomination are supposed to follow these pre-set religious standards, and when people do not conform, they are seen as less religious, deviant, or as followers of ‘folk religion’ or magic. This approach fails to take into account the great diversity in religious expressions and the experience of individuals. Meredith McGuire and others have therefore promoted a new way of understanding and studying religious behaviour. They advocate a bottom-up approach, in which scholars study religion as it is actually lived and experienced in peoples' everyday lives. Hence the terms ‘lived religion’ or ‘everyday religion’. They are interested in what people actually do, think, and say rather than in whether they fit the prearranged package. Religion is no longer seen as static, but as a dynamic field of change and tradition.

column10: Extra curricular course for VU students, Secondary subject for non-VU students, Open course
column12: In deze vierde module bezoek je verschillende plaatsen, instellingen, bewaarplaatsen en uitingen van religieus erfgoed, waar je in gesprek gaat met beheerders/gebruikers van dat erfgoed. Je doet daarnaast onderzoek naar één specifiek religieus object/gebouw/collectie in Amsterdam. Je oefent je om wetenschappelijk verantwoorde teksten te schrijven voor een breed publiek, om zo, binnen een gegeven (digitaal) format, bij te kunnen dragen aan de website Religieus Erfgoed Amsterdam op de kaart. In deze module zal worden samengewerkt met Museum Ons’ Lieve Heer op Solder te Amsterdam en met de Universiteitsbibliotheek van de Vrije Universiteit.

column10: Extra curricular course for VU students, Secondary subject for non-VU students
column12: In de vijfde module verdiep je je in de praktische, theoretische en ethische aspecten van de representatie van religie in musea en erfgoedinstellingen. We denken na over de wisselwerking tussen erfgoedgemeenschappen, erfgoedprofessionals en museumbezoekers, en de soms tegenstrijdige gevoelens die ‘religie als erfgoed’ oproept. We analyseren bestaande tentoonstellingen met religieuze objecten, en verkennen de kansen die een narratieve, immersieve en meerstemmige benadering biedt voor de interpretatie van religieus erfgoed. We kijken in deze module verder dan de kunst- of cultuurhistorische aspecten, en focussen op de verwijzende of bemiddelende rol van het religieuze object, de gebruiker(s), en de gebruikscontext. Ook vragen we ons af welke betekenissen mensen vandaag de dag aan het object toekennen, doordat of ondanks dat het is gemusealiseerd.

column10: Extra curricular course for VU students, Secondary subject for non-VU students, Open course
column12: In deze eerste module van de minor Religieus Erfgoed maak je kennis met verschillende concepten en benaderingen inzake religieus erfgoed, de ontwikkelingen in het onderzoek naar dat erfgoed, en het actuele beleid ten aanzien van gebouwd religieus erfgoed vanuit overheden en maatschappelijke partners. Je bestudeert het religieuze gebouw als heilige plaats, als multifunctionele ruimte, en als object van herbestemming. Met medestudenten bereid je een debat voor over de vraag ‘Van wie is het religieuze gebouw?’. Daarnaast oefen je jezelf in academische vaardigheden zoals het doen van literatuuronderzoek en het schrijven van een literatuurreview.

This course will provide theoretical and practical knowledge of and insights into contemporary issues in the field of employee recruitment, selection, and assessment. This knowledge is of utmost importance for SHRM graduates because recruitment and selection determine the quality of the employees in an organization and thereby impact the organization’s performance. Furthermore, numerous SHRM graduates are employed at consultancies/departments involved in recruitment, selection, and assessment. Organizational environments in which recruitment and selection instruments are being used have continued to evolve and generally become increasingly complex. This

column10: Extra curricular course for VU students, Secondary subject for non-VU students, Open course
column12: De reclassering vormt een belangrijke schakel in de strafrechtelijke reactie op criminaliteit. Mensen die in aanraking komen met justitie kunnen in alle fasen van het strafproces te maken krijgen met de reclassering. Jaarlijks heeft de reclassering contact met tienduizenden verdachten en veroordeelden en hiermee ziet de reclassering meer verdachten en veroordeelden dan het gevangeniswezen. De werkzaamheden van de reclassering zijn divers. Zo kan de reclassering al direct bij aanhouding een belangrijke rol spelen door het verlenen van zogenoemde vroeghulp aan verdachten die in het huis van bewaring verblijven, maar houdt de reclassering ook toezicht op opgelegde voorwaarden bijvoorbeeld bij een voorwaardelijke veroordeling of een voorwaardelijke invrijheidstelling en is de reclassering betrokken bij de coördinatie en uitvoering van taakstraffen. Deze uiteenlopende werkzaamheden maken dat de reclassering een centrale rol heeft in het strafrechtsysteem.

column10: Extra curricular course for VU students, Secondary subject for non-VU students
column12: Het recht speelt een belangrijke rol binnen de overheid, de non-profit sector en het bedrijfsleven. Voor overheidsinstanties zijn bijvoorbeeld het staatsrecht en bestuursrecht relevant, terwijl voor non-profit organisaties onder andere het subsidierecht en belastingrecht belangrijk zijn. Particuliere bedrijven hebben bij hun activiteiten veelvuldig te maken met rechtsgebieden als het arbeidsrecht en ondernemingsrecht. En voor alle organisaties, ongeacht of zij publiek dan wel privaat van aard zijn, geldt dat zij zich bijvoorbeeld aan de regels van het contracten­recht en strafrecht hebben te houden.

column1: The rule of law and fundamental rights
column10: Secondary subject for non-VU students, Open course
column12: We horen het de laatste jaren vaak: de rechtsstaat staat onder druk. Het bestuderen van de inrichting van de rechtsstaat en fundamentele rechten is dus meer dan ooit van belang. In dit vak gaan we nader in op actuele staatsrechtelijke vraagstukken die zowel institutioneel-organisatorisch als grondrechtelijk van aard kunnen zijn. Voorbeelden van vraagstukken die aan de orde kunnen komen: wat is de reikwijdte van de inlichtingenplicht van ministers en staatssecretarissen aan de Kamer? Is die plicht afdwingbaar? En hebben Kamerleden altijd recht op alle soorten informatie? Op welke manier wordt een kabinet geformeerd? Hoe heeft die procedure zich ontwikkeld, en wat zijn de haken en ogen eraan? Is constitutionele, rechtelijke toetsing wenselijk? En zo ja, aan welke grondwetsartikelen dan? Mag de overheid bij haar besluitvorming zonder meer gebruik maken van algoritmes, of demonstraties van belangengroepen verbieden? Welke waarborgen zouden hiervoor moeten gelden? Wat betekent dit alles voor de 'staat van de rechtsstaat'?

Dit houdt in dat je heuristische kennis krijgt van ook meer complexe statistiek (zoals bijvoorbeeld multilevel analyse, itemresponstheorie, etc) zonder dat je zelf direct deze technieken hoeft te kunnen toepassen op data. Ook word je bewust van verschillende valkuilen in onderwijsonderzoek die consequenties hebben voor de implicatie van resultaten van een studie voor de onderwijspraktijk. De Europese integratie, via de Europese Unie, heeft aanzienlijke veranderingen teweeggebracht in de manier waarop staten en individuen op het Europese continent met elkaar omgaan. Een cruciale drijvende kracht achter deze integratie zijn zowel het Europese Hof van Justitie als de nationale rechtbanken in de lidstaten. Zij spelen een belangrijke rol door actief de EU-wetgeving te interpreteren en toe te passen. Hierdoor worden belemmeringen voor handel en mobiliteit binnen de interne markt van de EU weggenomen, en dit geldt in toenemende mate voor steeds meer gebieden.

column1: Real Estate Economics and Finance Research Project
column10: Extra curricular course for VU students, Secondary subject for non-VU students, Part of an Exchange Programme
column11: Participation in the other courses within the minor.
column12: In this course, you will identify a relevant research topic in real estate economics and finance, write a paper about it and present your results. The research topic must be in the field of real estate economics and finance, broadly defined so as to include urban economics, spatial planning and behavioural economics aspects of real estate markets. The topic can be in any type of real estate including that used for commercial and non-profit purposes, land and infrastructure. The choice of the topic can be based on current new items, large societal

column10: Secondary subject for non-VU students, Part of an Exchange Programme
column12: The course covers micro- as well as macroeconomic and finance aspects, and residential as well as commercial real estate. Attention will be paid on search and matching issues and price formation. The durability of real estate facilitates the possible separation between ownership, which leads to issues of tenure choice. The design of buildings has important implications for pollution of greenhouse gases and the use of materials. The fixed location of buildings implies the capitalization of local public goods in its price. Housing is the largest expenditure category and for owners the house is often the dominant asset, implying a close connection between real estate markets and the wider economy. The relationships between real estate markets and urban planning will be explored. Students will be introduced to the CPB housing model used to assess housing policies. In a group assignment students will analyse housing policy measures in a real world setting on the basis of this model. Another assignment addresses the 'four quadrants' and the matching of houses and households.

column10: Extra curricular course for VU students, Secondary subject for non-VU students, Part of an Exchange Programme
column12: Cities have been described as the main human invention and their role in social and economic life is still expanding. To a large extend, cities 'are' real estate. A large part of the national capital stock consists of urban real estate. Within cities there is a concentration in a small number of centers and subcenters. The built environment is extremely durable, it will often remain in place for decades or even centuries. Investment decisions with

column10: Extra curricular course for VU students, Secondary subject for non-VU students, Part of an Exchange Programme
column12: Central to this course is the question: How do we “read” images? Like words, images can be understood as semiotic signs that require cultural training to decode. Moreover, particular ways of reading images can assist in the deconstruction of their ideological messages.

column1: Reading American Monuments: From the Puritans to Black Lives Matter
column10: Extra curricular course for VU students, Secondary subject for non-VU students, Part of an Exchange Programme
column12: American monuments reflect but also distort American history. In this course, we will study an array of historical and contemporary monuments that promote certain American myths, such as the Promised Land, the Self-Made Man, and the Myth of the West, but that also ignore other aspects, such as slavery and the oppression of minorities. Monuments are shaped by the times in which they were created, but their meanings are also affected by those who created them, and those who advocated or objected to them. Currently, many of the monuments that we will study are contested in the wake of the Black Lives Matter protests and counterprotests. Calls to either defend or deface or tear down statues and memorials have become increasingly politicized, making this theme highly relevant for the times in which we live. Students will also “adopt a monument” themselves, which will allow them to study why their chosen monument was created, what battles ensued before they were realized, and what contemporary value they still have.

Course Content

column1: Quantitative Research Methods III - Economics and Finance
column10: Secondary subject for non-VU students, Part of an Exchange Programme
column12: First of all, students get to know and learn about different data sources and to summarize data in a number of descriptive statistics. Second, they learn how to work with univariate and multivariate linear regression models. We also pay attention to situations where the classical assumptions of the linear regression model do not hold: think about problems such as multicollinearity, omitted variable bias, heteroskedasticity and endogeneity. Third, students will learn to work with Probit models (in case the outcome variable is binary) and they get to know the basics of time series and panel data models. Finally, students will apply the mentioned techniques with empirical data using R.

column1: Quantitative Research Methods III - Accounting and Marketing
column10: Secondary subject for non-VU students, Part of an Exchange Programme
column12: This course focuses on conducting research. This includes research design, selecting the appropriate methods, analysis and interpretation of the results. You will learn how to express theories as abstract models and how to correctly interpret the results of estimating these models. In this course we build on your statistical knowledge gained in Quantitative Research Methods II. We cover an extensive selection of advanced methods such as factor analysis and multiple regression analysis including methods to analyse moderating and mediating effects. You will learn how to implement these techniques in statistical software (R). The choice of the correct specification and the interpretation of the results will be central. We also discuss how to deal with limitations in the data.

column10: Secondary subject for non-VU students, Part of an Exchange Programme
column12: Economics is a scientific discipline in which quantitative data are key. Theoretical considerations of the effect of minimum wages on unemployment, or the effect of bonuses on the performance of employees, are useful, but the final test is not the theory but confrontation with practical data. Unfortunately such data are rarely if ever completely unambiguous. Business cycles go up one day, and go down the other day, and usually there are more factors to cause noise in the data. Statistics provides means to draw reliable conclusions from data. The modern economist must therefore be able to handle statistics and to handle statistical software to visualize data. In this course such skills are taught: statistical analyses connected to theoretical topics are carried out using R.

column10: Secondary subject for non-VU students, Part of an Exchange Programme
column12: In Business and Economics, we use many mathematical models and techniques. For instance, the conditions for market and price equilibrium can be formulated mathematically. Similarly, we can use mathematics to quantify risk and optimize investment portfolios. As a result, mathematics is a challenging, but highly relevant topic for students in Business and Economics.

Quantitative research methods refer to the systematic empirical investigation of social phenomena via statistical, mathematical, or computational techniques. The objective of quantitative research is to determine the existence and magnitude of a relation between constructs (e.g., education and performance) that are of interest to the researcher. This course is meant to familiarize you with the research process starting from a research question to collecting data, analysing data, and writing a scientific research paper. The goal of the course is to help you prepare for your academic paper and for your Master’s thesis and to help you understand and critically evaluate the scientific articles that you read while studying or while looking for state-of-the art information about topics you encounter in your (working) life.

column10: Extra curricular course for VU students, Secondary subject for non-VU students, Part of an Exchange Programme

column1: Quantitative Research and Methods in Political Science
column12: In an era in which quantitative data drives decision-making across sectors, this course equips students with the necessary tools to address questions in political science. The course aims to foster an understanding of how to apply data science techniques effectively. By bridging theoretical knowledge with practical skills in data analysis and causal reasoning, students will not only be prepared to engage with social science research but also gain a competitive edge in the data-driven job market. The goal is to cultivate a data literate generation of students capable of employing quantitative evidence to inform sound policy decisions.

column10: Secondary subject for non-VU students
column12: Financial markets enable entrepreneurs to raise capital from investors and thus facilitate economic growth. The markets further let investors share risk among themselves in the most efficient way. However, several frictions prevent these markets from functioning perfectly. In real-world markets, transactions are costly and price can become pressured for minutes, days, or weeks when investors demand liquidity. Extreme pressure regularly leads to price crashes. In this course, we will explore these frictions and how optimal design of markets can alleviate their harmful effects.

The goal of this course is to provide students with an adequate background in the methods of quantitative analyses of social science data. Students with a background in qualitative data analysis will focus on learning how to apply multiple regression techniques to analysing quantitative data. The course deepens their knowledge and understanding outcomes on methodology, specifically basic knowledge of and insight into quantitative methods and the basic skills to apply statistical methods to analyse data. Students learn to present research results and interpretations of data in a clear manner.

If we want to choose our partner or significant other, we cannot rely on some general statistics. We need to get in-depth, detailed knowledge of him/her. This requires close interactions, rich communication, and historical information. This is the gist of qualitative research. Of course, in this course we do not really talk about couples and personal relationships. We focus instead on learning how and why qualitative research is useful for understanding organizations and management.

column12: After a short introduction, conceptual foundations and definitions of public relations and reputation management are discussed. Next, the course Public Relations and Reputation Management analyses the interplay between organizations, media (framing, agenda building, news value), stakeholders and the role of corporate identity management for building reputation. Consequently, concrete strategies and effects of public relations and reputation management (e.g., media relations, communication plans) are introduced. Also, students learn about public relations and reputation management in specific areas such as Corporate Identity Management, Crisis Communication, Issue Management, Corporate Social Responsibility and Social Media PR.

column10: Secondary subject for non-VU students
column12: After a brief introduction to the field of Public Relations, forms and effects of communication between organizations, news media and audiences in the field of new media are discussed. Also discussed are concrete strategies and tools of Public Relations (issue, stakeholder and reputation management, responses to consumer behavior and media relations). Finally, specific applications of online Public Relations such as crisis communication, corporate social responsibility and internal communication are discussed.

column10: Secondary subject for non-VU students, Part of an Exchange Programme
column12: The course will address topics such as taxation of households and firms, tax incidence, public debt, distributional effects of taxation and public expenditure, theories of the state, efficiency and welfare, optimal taxation and Ramsey pricing, market failure, externalities, and non-local and local public goods. The twelve lectures will seek to not only make the technical treatment and theoretical concepts accessible, but also to draw the links with contemporary policy challenges.

column10: Secondary subject for non-VU students, Part of an Exchange Programme
column12: Public economics studies the economic role of the government from a positive perspective (what are the effects of government policies?) and a normative perspective (which policies should the government implement?). Public economics is thus a branch of applied welfare economics. This course covers a number of topics out of the following list:

Public economics studies the role of government in a market economy. A public finance perspective provides the main organizing principle: what are government tasks, what expenditures do they require, and what is a good way of financing them?

column10: Extra curricular course for VU students, Secondary subject for non-VU students, Open course, Part of an Exchange Programme
column12: The free market does not always deliver socially optimal outcomes. In such situations where markets fail, there is a potential role for government intervention. At the same time, government intervention can also have (sometimes unintended) side effects. In this course, the many aspects of government intervention in the economic process including its logic and legitimacy are discussed. Topics that are central are: (i) the role for the government in the economic process, (ii) externalities, (iii) public goods, (iv) labor markets and income  distribution (interpersonal and interregional), (v) optimal taxation, (vi) fiscal federalism and subsidiarity and (vii) location choice of firms and people. Much attention will be devoted to methods for policy evaluation, with special emphasis on cost-benefit analysis.

column10: Extra curricular course for VU students
column11: This course is part of the minor "Psychopathology, Health and Prevention". Therefore, it is advised to have passed the preminor "Emotion, Cognition and Behavior" (or equivalent) to start well-prepared. It's important that you have a basic understanding of the different psychological and neurological disorders (e.g., DSM-5 classifications), as the present course will built on to this knowledge and provide a more in-depth understanding of mechanisms that may play an important role in the development and maintenance of these disorders.
column12: The first step in psychological treatment is recognition: you need to be able to recognize, differentiate and classify the symptoms and problems that a patient presents in order to formulate a diagnosis and provide the right type of treatment. Therefore, this course will equip you with an in-depth understanding and critical awareness of the incidence, prevalence and presentation of common mental health and neurological disorders that develop throughout the lifespan. Additionally, we will discuss how these disorders can be explained from a biological, psychological or social perspective and what risk and protective factors may play a role in its development. Finally, this course teaches you how to distinguish between psychological disorders and how to make differential diagnoses. This knowledge forms the essential base that is needed to become a well-equipped mental health professional.

column7: Faculty of Behavioural and Movement Sc.
column12: Many patients treated in the more specialized Mental Health Care (GGZ) suffer from complex psychological problems. The aim of this course is to provide an overview of several specialized, state-of-the-art psychotherapies used in the GGZ. In the lectures, a number of prominent experts (researchers and practitioners) from clinical practice will talk about their experience with treating patients with psychological disorders such as personality disorders, chronic depression, obsessive-compulsive disorder, psychosis, complex trauma, eating disorders and forensic problems. They will discuss the scientific base of these treatments and mechanisms of action, but also appropriate indication and clinical application. Self-study of scientific literature belonging to the lectures will be used to deepen your understanding of the different treatments. Weekly reflection questions can be used to test your knowledge and think critically about the material.

column10: Extra curricular course for VU students, Secondary subject for non-VU students
column12: This course is an introduction to psycholinguistics, an interdisciplinary scientific field that integrates concepts and techniques from modern linguistics, psychology and neuroscience. It investigates and describes the mental processes involved in the production and comprehension of language. Through online lectures, assignments, and exercices you will find tools to approach and answer questions like: How do we produce, perceive and recognize spoken and written language? How do we acquire language(s)? How is linguistic knowledge represented, structured and stored in our mind and brain, and how is it used in the real-time processing of language?

column10: Extra curricular course for VU students, Secondary subject for non-VU students, Part of an Exchange Programme
column12: This course is an introduction to psycholinguistics, an interdisciplinary scientific field that integrates concepts and techniques from modern linguistics, psychology and neuroscience. It investigates and describes the mental processes involved in the production and comprehension of language. Through lectures, assignments, and hands-on sessions you will gain knowledge and learn skills and tools to address questions like: How do we produce, perceive and recognize spoken and written language? How do we acquire language(s)? How is linguistic knowledge represented, structured and stored in our mind and brain, and how this knowledge is used in the real-time processing of language?

column7: Faculty of Behavioural and Movement Sc.
column12: De cursus biedt inhoudelijke kennis en praktische vaardigheden met betrekking tot verdiepende psychodiagnostiek bij kinderen, jeugdigen en hun ouders. In de cursus komen ontwikkelingsaspecten en omgevingskenmerken aan de orde die relevant zijn voor de psychodiagnostiek van kinderen, adolescenten en hun ouders. Meer specifiek bespreken we de psychodiagnostiek van sociale en emotionele problemen, cognitieve functies en persoonlijkheidsproblemen bij kinderen en adolescenten (0‐24 jaar). Daarnaast is er aandacht voor relevante diagnostiek bij ouders (bijv. relatieproblematiek). Wetenschappelijke bevindingen op dit gebied vertalen we naar de klinische praktijk. Aan de hand van opdrachten leer je via casuïstiek meer over de achtergronden voor de keuze, de afname en de interpretatie van verschillende instrumenten. Als aankomend psychodiagnosticus leer je in de cursus je theoretische, methodische en persoonlijk-professionele reflectie over diagnostisch handelen te ontwikkelen en aan te scherpen.

It creates a "playground" where students can experiment with different testing techniques they learned during the Software Testing course. Moreover, testing is practised as just one phase in a more general, systems engineering process, where software meets hardware.The systems under test, a model railway and a salinity and temperature-controlled water plant, are inspired by real safety-critical systems, such as railway management systems and automatic insulin pumps.

column10: Extra curricular course for VU students, Secondary subject for non-VU students, Open course, Part of an Exchange Programme
column12: Since the mid of the 19th century, the production and use of chemicals have been increasing dramatically and nowadays play a crucial role in the functioning of our societies. In fact, the chemical industry nowadays has become one of the most important manufacturing industries from an economic perspective. From pharmaceuticals, all the way to textiles and plastics, chemicals are involved in almost everything that we do. Yet through their life cycle, from manufacturing, during usage and eventually, when they are being disposed of, chemicals can impact human health and the environment. Through voluntary or involuntary emissions in the air (e.g., atmosphere) and water (e.g., rivers), chemicals can enter the environment and influence entire ecosystems. These chemicals can eventually also affect human health as we ourselves are exposed to them through the air we breathe, the food we eat and the water we drink.

column10: Extra curricular course for VU students, Secondary subject for non-VU students, Open course, Part of an Exchange Programme
column12: Within this course students learn to address a societal challenge involving social interaction by means of agent-based simulation. They learn to identify relevant concepts and relations, formalise these in a dedicated environment (Netlogo), conduct simulations to test different hypothetical scenarios and analyse their results.

This course concludes the minor Situated AI. It is a full-time, 4 weeks course, in which students will work in groups on several practical assignments related to the other courses of the minor. One week will be devoted to building a robot application, another to the implementation of a conversational AI system, another week to the implementation of a reinforcement algorithm, and one to the application of logical reasoning. The different components will be combined in one application scenario, for which the students will build an demonstrator. Students will write a report about their demo and the choices made.

column1: Project Premaster: Communicatiewetenschapper in de maak
column12: Het vak dient om studenten verschillende belangrijke academische vaardigheden aan te leren. In dit vak maken studenten kennis met de verschillende onderdelen van de empirische cyclus, waarbij de nadruk ligt op het opzetten, uitvoeren, en rapporteren van empirisch onderzoek. Studenten zullen tijdens dit vak kennis opdoen over belangrijke literatuur-, schrijf-, onderzoeks- en statistische vaardigheden middels kennisclips, en zullen deze kennis vervolgens toepassen op communicatiewetenschappelijke vraagstukken en gegevens die tijdens het vak zullen worden verzameld. Studenten zullen individueel practica volgen waarin wordt geoefend met statistische analyses en de stof uit de statistiek kennisclips. Deze kennis zal worden getoetst middels twee deeltentamens. Daarnaast zal er in de werkgroepen worden geoefend met de stof uit de literatuur-, schrijf-, en onderzoeks kennisclips. Deze kennis zal worden getoetst middels een onderzoeksverslag over een kleinschalig empirisch onderzoek die wordt uitgevoerd in team verband in periode 4 en 5. Het empirisch onderzoek kent elementen van  inhoudsanalyse en experimenteel onderzoek.

During this second project course of the Communication Science bachelor program, students learn to apply the knowledge acquired during their courses by analyzing the public perception of an organization of choice. Working in a team and guided by one of the teachers, they analyze and evaluate the communication strategy of the organization. After that, as the core of this project course, they conduct an online survey to assess the public perception of the organization and variables that could influence this. Students are guided through the various phases of a quantitative study, from formulating a research question and direct effect hypotheses based on scientific literature, to the selection of measurements, programming the survey and data analyses.

Every day we receive a lot of information about the world around us
column13: this varies from events far away to personal events in our immediate environment. This information may have an impact on us –on our thoughts, emotions and behavior –and it may shape how we view the world, how we perceive reality. How do we determine whether information represents reality? Do we form our reality through the information we seek and receive? Is it problematic when we receive fake information? When and how do we perceive information as real or relevant?

column12: Deze cursus is het eerste van de vier projecten in deleerlijn professionele vaardigheden. In deze projecten oefen je steeds met een van de vier professionele rollen die we onderscheiden. Dit zijn achtereenvolgens beleidsadviseur, opdrachtonderzoeker, sociaal ondernemer en consultant. Kenmerkend voor de cursussen in deze leerlijn is de transdisciplinaire benadering. Dit betekent dat je werkt aan een opdracht van een partij van buiten de universiteit en de uitkomst ook aan die opdrachtgever presenteert.

column10: Extra curricular course for VU students, Secondary subject for non-VU students, Open course, Part of an Exchange Programme
column12: This course discusses how to write computer programs that can run in parallel on a large number of processors with the main goal of reducing execution time and solving large problems that cannot fit in a single compute node. You will learn how to design such parallel algorithms in order to minimize communication overhead and load imbalance, how to implement them using different parallel computing models, and how to analyze the performance of the resulting codes and the underlying hardware. Among all parallel programming models and environments available for High Performance Computing, this course focuses on distributed-memory parallelization. You will learn established techniques such as message-passing with MPI, but also more modern approaches like the task-based distributed-computing model provided by the Julia programming language. Several parallel applications are discussed in the course, including partial differential equations, deep learning, N-body simulation, and search algorithms.

column1: Professional opportunities and personal well-being: Working and studying in the field of international crimes
column12: Studying and working in the field of international crimes is not only difficult because it is intellectually demanding but also because it can be emotionally challenging. Both during their studies, as well as their careers afterwards, those focusing on conflict related crimes are confronted with the hardship of others which may negatively impact their personal wellbeing. It is, therefore, important to learn how to cope with these emotions, be there for others who may struggle with these emotions, as well as to find out which kind of career path is best for them personally.

Daarnaast leer je welke pedagogische en didactische adviezen je leerkrachten kan geven om aan te sluiten bij de ondersteuningsbehoeften van leerlingen (bijv. leerlingen met ASS, leerlingen met problemen met executieve functies, dyslexie). Achtereenvolgens worden de volgende thema's behandeld: Het werkveld van de schoolpsycholoog, Leerkracht-leerling relatie en interactie, Pedagogische en didactische adviezen, Dyslexie, Sociale relaties en groepsdynamiek

column1: Problematic and Beneficial Effects of Media Use
column10: Secondary subject for non-VU students, Part of an Exchange Programme
column12: If a new medium enters society it raises concerns and public debates. Some people are euphoric and optimistic, but many fear the new medium will result in a cultural decline. Currently, we see the same debates evolving around AI or ChatGPT, Virtual Reality or the metaverse, or Social Robots (and before these: the book, comic books, film, video games, personal computers, the Internet...). We are also still very much debating the pros and cons of social media in society.

column12: From the book by From Pishro-Nik:

Dynamical systems come across in many fields: for example climatology, biology, and engineering. If the initial condition of a dynamical system is uncertain, then probabilistic forecasting is used to provide a set of plausible predictions with probability assigned to it. The aim of the course is to describe the mathematical and algorithmic principles of probabilistic forecasting of dynamical systems.

column12: Private international law is the branch of law that deals with the regulation of cross-border relationships in private law.  It includes international jurisdiction, conflict of laws (applicable law), recognition and enforcement of foreign judgments and procedural cooperation. This course deals with topics of private international law that are particularly relevant in the context of cross-border trade and commercial disputes. Students will study EU regulations (e.g. Brussels I recast, Rome I and Rome II), relevant case law of the CJEU and a selection of international treaties (e.g. Hague Choice of Court Convention
column13: Hague Judgment Convention) on international jurisdiction, applicable law and/or recognition and enforcement of foreign judgments with regard to contract law, tort law, insolvency law and company law.

column10: Secondary subject for non-VU students, Open course
column12: ‘Voor advocaten is privacy een vakgebied met een rijke toekomst’ kopte een artikel in het advocatenblad van 2011. Tien jaar later blijkt de kop aardig te kloppen, onder andere met dank aan de enorme boetebevoegdheid die de Autoriteit Persoonsgegevens heeft gekregen en inmiddels ook inzet. De opkomst van privacy als een populair punt van geschillen vindt onder andere zijn oorzaak in de vergaande digitalisering van het maatschappelijke leven, maar ook de bereidheid van overheden en bedrijven om hier gebruik van te maken. Daarmee is het niet alleen relevant voor advocaten, maar dringt het belang van privacy en gegevensbescherming langzaamaan door tot de rest van de samenleving.

column12: Lectures, working groups and hands-on training

column11: -         A completed master's degree in dentistry
column12: This course covers the biological, anatomical and biomechanical principles of oral implantolgy. The theoretical foundations of oral implantology are covered. The student is aware of the right indications and surgical treatment plans for implant treatment based on sound scientific knowledge. The history and characteristics of different implants and ACTA's preferred implant systems will be discussed. Various parameters that affect implant selection and surgical treatments are taught during this course. In addition, the course will focus on anatomy of the head and neck region, the appropriate use of local anesthesia, preoperative and postoperative medications. Indications for implants and the possible complications in patients with medical problems are discussed.

column10: Extra curricular course for VU students, Secondary subject for non-VU students, Open course, Part of an Exchange Programme
column12: This course is designed for students with an interest in life sciences and the biotech/pharmaceutical industry but without prior education in this field. A general introduction will be given to the process of drug discovery, drug design and synthesis, drug development and drug safety assessment. Subsequently, potential drug targets, mechanisms of drug actions (including drug- receptor/enzyme interactions and dose- response relations), drug disposition (including pharmaco-/toxicokinetics) and drug toxicity will be discussed. Various modern developments and tools will be illustrated by recent applications in the field of drug discovery.

column12: De verantwoordelijkheid voor de gezondheid is steeds meer bij het individu komen te liggen. We maken immers zelf onze leefstijlkeuzes, zoals wel of niet voldoende bewegen, gezond eten of roken. Toch komt er steeds meer bewustzijn dat ook andere partijen verantwoordelijk zijn voor het stimuleren van een gezonde leefstijl. Zoals het ministerie van Volksgezondheid, Welzijn en Sport in 2011 schreef in de landelijke nota gezondheidsbeleid ‘Gezondheid Dichtbij’: een gezonde leefstijl is nog steeds primair de verantwoordelijkheid van het individu, maar ook partijen zoals zorgverleners, zorgverzekeraars, scholen, werkgevers en de overheid spelen een rol in de bevordering van gezond gedrag. Deze partijen hebben de verantwoordelijkheid om een sociale, culturele, economische en fysieke omgeving op te bouwen waarin gezond gedrag de makkelijkste en aantrekkelijkste keus is voor het individu. Want zoals steeds meer duidelijk wordt: de omgeving heeft een minsten zo grote
