column1: Preminor Praktijken van Pedagogische Hulpverlening, Zorgintensieve Kinderen
column7: Faculty of Behavioural and Movement Sc.
column12: Het vak start met vier voorbereidende werkgroepen, gericht op pedagogische theorieën en hulpverleningstechnieken. De studenten krijgen dan ook een gastles van een ouder van een zorgintensief kind. Tijdens de periode waarin de huisbezoeken plaatsvinden volgen de studenten ook werkgroepen ter begeleiding. Er is dan gelegenheid om met elkaar te reflecteren, discussiëren, vragen te stellen, verschillen tussen gezinnen te bespreken, en om tussentijds feedback te krijgen op de opdrachten van de docent. Na de huisbezoeken is er een laatste afrondende werkgroep.  De studenten maken verschillende deelopdrachten, onderverdeeld in hun persoonlijke ontwikkeling: studenten reflecteren op hun eigen handelen, rol, persoonlijke voorkeuren, sterke punten en valkuilen in het contact met het gezin, en een eindverslag over de huisbezoeken: ze beschrijven hun eigen ervaring van de huisbezoeken en gaan ook in op een bepaald thema binnen het gezin. De student krijgt de opdracht om tijdens de huisbezoeken in te gaan op verschillende thema’s: 1) de relatie met de brusjes (broertjes/zusjes), 2) het zorgnetwerk om het kind heen, of 3) het verwerkingsproces binnen het gezin. Hoe gaat het bijvoorbeeld met de brusjes van een zorgintensief kind, wat voor impact heeft het leven met een zorgintensief brusje op hen? Of welke zorgprofessionals zijn er allemaal betrokken bij het kind? Hoe werken die samen met elkaar en met het gezin? En hoe gaat de ouder bijvoorbeeld om met gevoelens van verdriet (levend verlies) als mijlpalen niet worden behaald door het kind? De student zal in het gezin observeren en gaat met het gezin in gesprek door te luisteren en te vragen naar belevingen, en zal waar mogelijk meegaan naar afspraken.

column1: Preminor LPSI part 2 Power and Social Influence
column7: Faculty of Behavioural and Movement Sc.
column12: Power and social influence are fundamental concepts in social sciences. However, people normally approach these topics as taboo. Their study is, however, crucial to understand group functioning and social interactions at large. In this course we will study the topics of power and social influence from a social psychological perspective. Some important questions that will be addressed in the course are: How do people and groups influence others? What are the sources of power and of social influence in social groups? Is power imbalance in a group advantageous? How do people react to power when is used to influence them?

column7: Faculty of Behavioural and Movement Sc.
column12: Leadership is a fundamental part of life in general, and organizational life in particular. In all aspects of life, you encounter leaders. From the captain of your sports team, to your supervisor at work, to the president of your country
column13: leadership is all around. In a world where these leaders make decisions that affect millions of lives it is important to understand why leaders behave the way they do, what type of leadership behaviors are (in)effective, and why groups follow some, but not other, leaders. This course provides an overview of the leadership literature and motivates students to apply this knowledge to the organizational work setting and real-life cases. Moreover, students will reflect on their own leadership and followership qualities and characteristics.

column1: Pre-Master Tutorial Academic Writing Social and Cultural Anthropology
column12: The practice of academic writing will be introduced in the lectures. Students will practice academic writing in small assignments with a focus on feedback and repeated improvement. The first session will focus on technical and stylistic aspects of academic texts. The afternoon program introduces a selection of anthropological key texts to be read and/or summarized in written assignments. Eventually, students will write an essay about the nature and objective of anthropological research, using the texts read in the course.

This course provides a general introduction to major concepts and key approaches in political science. It consists of two parts. In the first part, a critical overview is given of several key concepts and their position within political science such as ‘ideology’, ‘power’, ‘legitimacy’, ‘the state’, ‘the nation’ and ‘democracy’, as well as contending perspectives on conflict and cooperation within modern political systems. We will also discuss contemporary political phenomena (manifest in many different countries) such as the rise of populism. Thus, the first part of the course primarily focuses on concepts and topics related to the sub-discipline of Comparative Politics. The second part of the course introduces students to contemporary world politics and the main concepts and theories in the sub-discipline of International Relations. It first provides an overview of international political history from the 17th century to the present. We then seek to understand history by identifying recurrent patterns of cooperation and conflict between and within states, looking at the role of both state- and non-state actors. We will also apply some of the concepts that we discussed in the first part of the course. The second part of the course will be concluded with a discussion of several key features of and developments in contemporary global politics, such as the role of the UN, current international conflicts, the information revolution and the growing web of transnational relations.

Als socioloog moet je in staat zijn om maatschappelijke vraagstukken beter te begrijpen en op basis daarvan interventies te ontwerpen of te verbeteren die kunnen bijdragen aan de aanpak daarvan. Je hebt vast een – common sense – idee van wat wordt bedoeld met maatschappelijke vraagstukken en kan waarschijnlijk ook wel een aantal voorbeelden noemen (armoede, diversiteit, werkloosheid, onveiligheid). Maar wat maakt een vraagstuk eigenlijk eenmaatschappelijk vraagstuk? We zullen zien dat het bepaald niet eenvoudig is om een maatschappelijk vraagstuk scherp te definiëren en analyseren, maar ook dat juist hiervoor de sociologische blik van grote waarde is.

Deze cursus is onderdeel van de leerlijn Onderzoeksvaardigheden. De cursus bestaat uit twee delen. In het eerste deel maak je kennis met de theorievorming van kwalitatief onderzoek waarbij aandacht besteed wordt aan de onderzoeksparadigma’s, de kenmerken van kwalitatief onderzoek, reflexiviteit en het onderzoeksontwerp. Je krijgt meer inzicht in de logica van verschillende kwalitatieve onderzoeksmethoden. Er wordt verwacht dat je de literatuur van tevoren leest, de kennisclips van tevoren bekijkt en de werkgroepen actief volgt. Het eerste deel sluit je af met een take-home tentamen. In de werkgroepen wordt de theoretische kennis toegepast en er wordt intensief geoefend voor het take-home tentamen.

column12: In het vak Kernthema’s Organisatiewetenschappen wordt een overzicht gegeven van de hoofdstromen in de bestuurs- en organisatiewetenschappen en de voornaamste theorieën en theoretici binnen elke stroming. De student leert bestuur en organisaties bestuderen vanuit uiteenlopende invalshoeken. Het vak biedt inzicht in specifieke onderwerpen, zoals rationele versus sociale bestuursstijlen, formele modellen versus feitelijke praktijken, de relatie organisatie-omgeving, cultuur en symboliek, macht en organisatiepolitiek, en "nieuwe" organisatievormen

This course provides an introduction to the statistical methods of social science research. It teaches necessary basics of quantitative data analysis to 1st year undergraduate students of various programs of the Faculty of Social Sciences (FSS). Students develop skills to process and manipulate collected quantitative data to prepare for statistical analyses. They learn to describe the data in terms of central tendency and distribution of variables. In addition to summarizing data by using numbers, students gain insights and skills in how to visualise numerical information and make graphs. Students also learn to describe, explain and visualise relationships between variables.

column12: In het keuzevak Praktijkonderzoek staat het leren toepassen van onderzoeksvaardigheden in de onderwijspraktijk centraal. In dit keuzevak leer je een actieonderzoek opzetten en uitvoeren ten behoeve van je eigen professionalisering. Vaak wordt een professionaliseringsvraag breder gedeeld in je sectie/school. Actieonderzoek is een vorm van onderzoekend leren. Je gebruikt theorie en bevindingen uit onderwijsonderzoek om jouw praktijkprobleem te analyseren en om ontwerp/voornemens te formuleren. Je leert hoe je in je klassen data kan verzamelen over de invloed van jouw ontwerp, op de leerprocessen van je leerlingen.

column1: Praktijken van Pedagogische Hulpverlening: Theoretische Benaderingen
column7: Faculty of Behavioural and Movement Sc.
column12: In dit onderdeel verdiepen studenten zich in directe pedagogische hulpverlening aan kinderen en cliënten (bv. interventies en begeleiding) en begeleiders en opvoeders (bv. advies, ondersteuning, begeleiding). De basis van veel van de methodieken voor hulpverlening wordt gevormd door een aantal theoretische kaders, zoals de leertheorie, gehechtheidstheorie, systeemtheorie en psychodynamische theorieën. Daarnaast zijn er specifieke werkwijzen, zoals solution-focused therapy en cognitieve gedragstherapie. Aan de hand van case-studies zal effectmeting vanuit verschillende theoretische kaders worden toegelicht. Dit zijn ook voorbeelden van de toepassing van interventies in de praktijk.

column10: Extra curricular course for VU students, Secondary subject for non-VU students, Open course, Part of an Exchange Programme
column12: The course primarily focuses on an integrative approach for practical theology, the approach that combines the hermeneutical, empirical, and strategic (critical) perspective in practical theology. The integrative approach requires an interrelationship between different branches of theology and enables practical theology to enter into sincere dialogue with the social sciences in order both to interpret contexts and practices as well as to think creatively about the development of new strategies and practices. The course also represents the vital relevance of the concept of lived religion to the study of practical theology. It helps students to understand the lived particularities of different societal and ecclesial challenges as embodied practices in which (religious) stories and narratives are created, transformed, and shared. This course also has a philosophical component and introduces virtue ethics.

column1: PPE in Practice I: Wellbeing, Politics and Markets
column12: The goal of this course is to obtain a better understanding of policy issues at the intersections of the three PPE disciplines. Students learn to apply theoretical insights and scientific findings to topical and often controversial issues, such as gambling, animal experiments, poverty relief, global warming, and international trade. The course deals with the relationship between politics, economics, and philosophy (in particular ethics) in the context of discussions about the working of markets and their limits in the light of market failures as well as the role that governments and other actors (such as NGOs, companies, citizens) are or are not to play in promoting and preserving individual and social welfare. Thus, the possibilities, limitations, and justifications of public policy proposals in a wide variety of different domains will be assessed. The course includes a language component that focuses on the following core linguistic features of academic English and lexical and grammatical pitfalls. In addition, instruction is given on conference presentation techniques.

column12: Gedurende het eerste jaar van je studie ‘Creatief Schrijven Nederlands’ heb je een aantal teksten geschreven en verzameld in je portfolio. Ook heb je in cursussen geleerd over de productie, distributie en receptie van literatuur
column13: in sommige colleges werd in het bijzonder aandacht besteed aan het uitgeven van teksten. In het vak ‘Pop-up Uitgeverij’ gaan jullie die zaken bij elkaar brengen. Met de eigen geschreven teksten uit het portfolio én nieuw werk, gaan jullie in groepsverband een (e-)magazine maken. Je leert daarbij de problemen en dilemma’s die bij het uitgeven van een tekst een rol spelen van binnenuit kennen. Daarbij verdiep je je kennis van het uitgeverijwezen. Elk jaar heeft het magazine een ander thema dat jullie zelf mogen kiezen - zolang het maar een band heeft met literatuur en samenleving en zolang het maar rekening houden met de interesses van het publiek dat jullie beogen. Jullie zijn vrij om in overleg met je team en de hoofdredacteur teksten en media in allerlei soorten en maten aan te leveren als deze maar te maken hebben met het door jullie gekozen centrale thema. Eén tekst staat vast: iedereen schrijft een eigen zogenoemde longread over een onderwerp naar keuze dat te maken heeft met het thema van jullie tijdschrift. Iedereen heeft tijdens het maakproces minstens twee verschillende rollen.

column10: Extra curricular course for VU students, Secondary subject for non-VU students
column12: The Central European heartlands of the former Habsburg monarchy have only recently became part of a wider narrative on European colonialism. Traditionally devoid of a colonial past, nations such as Austria, Czechia, Hungary, and others tend to fall out of the scholarly and public view as we discuss more familiar imperial projects under the British, French, Portuguese, and Spanish empires. Forming a somewhat exceptionalist debate, the purpose of this course is to interrogate the interactions between Central Europeans and the wider world along (post-)colonial lines of enquiry and to establish modes of historical understanding that reinterpret the Central European region for course participants. Acknowledging the role of Habsburg colonialism whether it be economic ventures in the Pacific, territorial takeover in East Africa, or finding colonial surrogates closer to home forms the bedrock for an opportunity for all Europeans to grapple with less-than-obvious colonial legacies.

Ook besteden we aandacht aan andere actuele thema’s die voer zijn voor discussie in de politiewetenschap en veiligheidszorgpraktijk, zoals diversiteit, evidence-based policing, en internationale opsporing.

column1: Political Science Research: Philosophy and Design
column12: In this course, we reflect upon the fundamental choices in developing a research design in political science. Starting from the question how to construct a research puzzle, we analyse the main choices involved in formulating hypotheses, selecting cases, measuring variables, and identifying and analysing your data. You practice these choices by developing a portfolio in which you apply your knowledge to a research problem of your choice.

Political science examines the ways in which conflicts between interests and values are resolved. This course offers an introduction to political science, covering both domestic politics and international politics. It follows a thematic structure. It starts with an analysis of key concepts in political science, such as the state, democracy and power. Next, it investigates key institutions and organizations in domestic politics, including constitutions, elections, governments, political parties and interest groups. The last part explores topics in international relations, such as warfare, regional integration and

The search for justice has been a central theme in human history. The political and institutional implementation of the ideals of justice has traditionally been assumed to be restricted to the confines of the modern nation-state. This course considers questions of justice that go beyond these confines. Questions we will address include:

This course offers a systematic and rigorous overview of different theories and developments in political philosophy. The course starts with a discussion of the possible justification of the state and the challenges of anarchism. It then turns to a discussion of some central approaches within political philosophy, including libertarianism, Marxism, communitarianism and multiculturalism. The discussion will link the central ideas to the analysis of key institutions (markets, civil society, democracy) as well as to more recent discussions about activism and civil disobedience.

column10: Extra curricular course for VU students, Secondary subject for non-VU students, Part of an Exchange Programme
column12: Political philosophy or political theory (often used interchangeably) deals with hot topics in today’s society. Together we explore the ideas and visions that people use when designing, redesigning or assessing the way their society is organized. In this course you get to know the most important past and contemporary ideologies within the modern political spectrum, such as liberalism, socialism, feminism, ecological thinking. We also look - particularly during the lectures - at the historical-cultural background of these ideologies: where do they come from, what are the core ideas?

column10: Extra curricular course for VU students, Secondary subject for non-VU students
column12: You will read several classical texts from the 20th century on education, from authors such as John Dewey, Carter G. Woodson, W.E.B. Du Bois, Ivan Illich and Paulo Freire. Where Dewey's work philosophically analysed how schooling could and should play a central role in a democratic state, Woodson and Du Bois highlighted how it failed Black citizens in the US. Illich and Freire both reflected on how education could emancipate the poor in South America as well as globally. In order to do so they proposed significant changes to current ideas and systems of education. Reflecting on the texts by means of personal assignments, group discussions, and additional research resulting in writing your own paper on the topic, you will appropriate the means to think critically about school education in relation to the role of the modern state in providing equal opportunities for all citizens to lead a meaningful life, that is based on personally chosen goals and the right education to achieve them.

This Physical Organic Chemistry course aims to cultivate critical thinking and problem-solving skills. Students will delve into the fundamental principles governing molecular reactivity, exploring topics such as catalyst-driven reaction rate modifications, acid/base catalysis, carbocation/carbanion chemistry, chemical bonding, stereochemistry, isotope effects, and reaction mechanisms. Through hands-on exercises, students will learn to formulate arrow-pushing mechanisms for experimental observations, assess existing theories, design validating experiments, and evaluate alternative explanations. The course equips students with the tools to navigate a wide range of fields, from foundational organic reactions to the complexities of supramolecular interactions and biomolecular recognition, fostering a deep understanding of the dynamic world of chemical reactions and molecular interactions.

column12: Social science features prominently in public discourse. Social scientists frequently make the news, they appear on talkshows, and are called upon to explain and interpret social developments and processes. Policy making sometimes also draws heavily on findings from the social sciences. The role of social science in society is just one example that raises fundamental philosophical questions about the nature and responsibilities of the social sciences.

column10: Extra curricular course for VU students, Secondary subject for non-VU students, Part of an Exchange Programme
column12: The relationship between the mind and the body has puzzled philosophers for centuries, giving rise to the notorious ‘mind-body problem’. In this introductory course, students will gain insight into the diverse range of philosophical positions proposed to grapple with this enigma, including substance and property dualism, behaviorism, identity theory, functionalism, computationalism, and eliminativism. We will examine the strengths, weaknesses, and implications of each perspective, shedding light on the complexity inherent in understanding the nature of the mind and its relation to the physical world. In addition to traditional approaches, this course will also delve into 4E approaches, which emphasize the embodied, embedded, enacted, and extended nature of cognition. Finally, students will apply these theories to specific case studies, reflecting on the distinctive challenges they present. What is consciousness and how could we explain it in scientific terms? How do we manage to understand other humans and which epistemic strategies do we rely on? Do we possess a free will, or are our actions always predetermined?

column1: Philosophy of International Law and Migration
column10: Secondary subject for non-VU students, Open course, Part of an Exchange Programme
column12: What is the relation between inclusion and exclusion in international law and migration? Is a world order conceivable with open borders, or no borders at all? What would that entail for questions of hospitality, sovereignty and the normative claims of international law and global justice? And what about the other way around: full exclusion by means of rigorous control of borders, is that plausible? Or is inclusion the inevitable counter-part of exclusion, meaning that the two are mutually exclusive while at the same time in constant need of each other?

column12: Hegel's writing "Grundlinien der Philosophie des Rechts oder Naturrecht und Staatswissenschaft im Grundrisse" ("Elements of the Philosophy of Right Or Natural Law and Political Science in Outline"), was first published in 1821. It is one of the outstanding classics of the legal philosophical tradition as well as Hegel’s most influential and most controversial work. Its leading thought is that of freedom and justice. In his Grundlinien, as an intrinsic part of Hegel’s speculative-idealist system of philosophy, Hegel aims to reconcile the ancient idea of the polis with the modern idea of autonomy, integrating modern law and morality.

column12: This course aims to introduce you to the philosophical school called Pragmatism. As the name suggests, Pragmatists in philosophy place special focus on social practices and questions of practical relevance. For example, Pragmatists tend to reject certain notions of truth where whether a statement is true or false will make no practical difference. Pragmatism can be considered a form of postmodernism.

column12: This course provides students with the means to understand organizational change. Towards this end we will go through main theoretical perspectives on organizational change. These perspectives share an aim to understand and explain how organizations adapt to changing environments through organizational change but they differ in key assumptions concerning how to conceptualize and understand organizational change. You will learn about these different perspectives not only during lectures but also by engaging in academic debates. During the tutorials you will debate against each other with the goal to argue for and defend a particular perspective. In addition to helping you to be able to explain these theoretical perspectives, the debates will improve your professional social skills related to creating and holding ground in a discussion.
